content.description: There are two problems here. Both are V0-V1ish. Dead hang start. Climb bulge to top
content.protection: Pad. Maybe a spotter. Use good judgment.
content.location: If you are facing tsunami arete and the tongue, these problems are going to be at your 7 o'clock about 20 yards behind you. Climb up the rock pile in front of tsunami and they will be facing up the canyon. They are very short problems.

content.description: Awkward lay (read ass backwards) start on bottom right of Tsunami Boulder. Climb up and right on arete. The holds on the arete are somewhat less than desirable and the feet are awkward. Some people love this problem though!
content.location: This is the boulder that looks like a giant 10 foot wave. It is behind the entrance wall and to the left of "the tongue".

content.description: Amazing Dyno problem! Start on block in middle of boulder. Balls up and throw right to top or get those feet up and go static. Top out from the lip.
content.protection: Pad and spotter. If you throw you don't have to worry about hitting the ledge on the left side. If you chicken out and don't throw you are more likely to get hurt. Use good judgment!
content.location: This is the boulder that looks like a giant 10 foot wave. It is behind the entrance wall and to the left of "the tongue".

content.description:
Sit start on right side with your heel scummed in the crack. Move around the tongue using the large ledge at the lip of the tongue. Top out.  

  Also goes around V3ish if you skip the outer ledge at the tip of the tongue and just shoot straight under for the bomber hold.
content.location: This is one of the most climbed problems at South Mountain. It is the very distinct feature behind the warm up wall that is often described as: the lizard head, iguana head, alligator head or tongue. It sits about 3 or 4 feet off the ground and is a great low ball!

content.description: Start on shelf in back of overhang. Come out of overhang using the side pull and a solid cam of the foot. Really awkward top out!
content.location: This is in the entrance boulders. It is the left most route on the overhang to the left of Tsunami (ie up canyon from tsunami).

content.description: Start on obvious flake on roof (same start as fisticuffs). Climb left and top out.
content.protection: Pad and spotter. There is a boulder on the left that could easily break an ankle without spotting and a pad.
content.location: This is the boulder on the left side of the trail after scrambling up the boulders from 'the tongue' and 'tsunami boulder'. It is before 'hookers are fun'. It also contains the problems 'fisticuffs' and 'double fisted'.

content.description: To the right of Table Topper
content.protection: To the right of Table Topper. Right most route in overhang that is just left of tsunami in the entrance boulders.

content.description: Sit start on huge horn (this is the same start is Crown of Thorns). Climb right. Top out.
content.protection: pad and spotter. beware of crumbly top.
content.location: Middle left side of the entrance wall.This is the first wall you see walking up the wash from the main trail.

climbs.name: Pima Traverse
climbs.fa: Manny Rangel and Jay Anderson, mid 80's

content.description: This is the obvious horizontal seam splitting the lower half of the Entrance boulder. Start left at Gimmie Some and traverse right till you can step off onto some raised boulders.
content.protection: Perhaps a pad at the start or near the end
content.location: Entrance boulder: approach as for the rest of Pima Canyon

content.description:
DANGER: The rock on this route has flexed and weakened over years of use, especially people climbing after rains, before the rock dries out. The large slab that forms the rail WILL BREAK and there is a possibility the climber could be crushed underneath it. Proceed using caution, or not at all.

 Start in back left of overhang using the big hold under the roof. Pop out to the lip and traverse the lip into the large pockets/huecos. Top out in middle.

 There is also a V2/3ish traverse that continues the entire length of the roof and tops out at the far right end.
content.protection:
You may want to have some one pull a pad as you traverse because you will have your hands and heels committed as you traverse the lip. This is often done w/o pads and it is only a 2 or 3 foot fall.

 Beware of the rock flexing and the potential to crush the climber.Â
content.location: From the Entrance boulders (the area with Tsunami Arete and the Tongue), continue up the wash 2 or 3 minutes. The wash will flatten out into a little plateau. This short flat area will lead up to a wall that is maybe 15 or 20 feet tall without any climbs. It is obvious that water sometimes runs over this wall. In the center of the wash before this wall is the overhang with Hookers are Fun. There may not be chalk on the outer parts but there will almost certainly be chalk on the inner lip. It is to the right of the trail that goes up the canyon.

content.description: Sit start on far left side of entrance wall. Work up to large blocks. And top out.
content.protection: Far left side of entrance wall. This is the first wall you see walking up the wash from the main trail. This is the shortest problem on the wall.
content.location: Pad. Beware that one of the blocks is very lose! It still can go at V0/V1 w/o using the lose block. I have seen 200+ lbs guys pull on the lose block though and it hasn't dislodged... Use good judgment...

content.description: Start on obvious roof flake (same start as 'stairway to heaven'). Climb right and up bulge.
content.location: This is the boulder on the left side of the trail after scrambling up from the entrance boulders. I call this area upper entrance boulders. The boulder also contains the problems 'Double Fisted' and 'Stairway to Heaven'.

content.description: Start in large Hueco on the upfill side of the boulder. Traverse the rail left and up. The first few moves are v-easy and a really fun. Rating comes from top out!
content.location: This is the boulder on the left side of the trail after scrambling up from the entrance boulders. I call this area upper entrance boulders. The boulder also contains the problems 'fisticuffs' and 'stairway to heaven'.

content.description: Link Pima Traverse into Crown Jewel. Start on the far left side of the Entrance Wall. Step off of the boulder and traverse the wall to the right finishing on top of Crown Jewel.
Sit start on huge horn (this is the same start is Silly Little Dirty). Climb bulge. Top out.
content.protection: pad and spotter. beware of crumbly top.
content.location: Middle left side of the entrance wall.This is the first wall you see walking up the wash from the main trail.

content.description: Sit start on far right crimp. The crimp is somewhat large but most climbers will have a hard time getting their butts off the ground. Stand up to large blocks in crack. Work up crimps to a sketchy top out. The tough parts are the very bottom and the very top. The middle section is just plain fun though!
content.protection: 2 pads and a spotter. It is kinda tall and the top is crumbly. A fall from the top is high but it is onto flat ground.
content.location: Right side of the entrance wall.This is the first wall you see walking up the wash from the main trail.

content.description: This is in Pima Canyon and it is the first wall you see when coming from the parking area. This is where the majority of people climb at South Mountain and it contains a few gems. Beware of crumbly top outs on the entrance wall!
